Module kivakit.core
Package com.telenav.kivakit.core.thread

Class Batcher<Element>

java.lang.Object
com.telenav.kivakit.core.messaging.broadcasters.Multicaster
com.telenav.kivakit.core.messaging.repeaters.BaseRepeater
com.telenav.kivakit.core.thread.Batcher<Element>
All Implemented Interfaces:
Broadcaster, Listener, Repeater, Transceiver, Receiver, Transmitter, NamedObject
public class Batcher<Element> extends BaseRepeater
A Batcher has a queue of element batches which are processed by one or more worker threads.

Adding Elements

New elements are added via a Batcher.BatchAdder object that is not thread-safe and should be kept only in a local variable or on a per-thread basis using ThreadLocal. A batch adder is created by a call to adder() and objects are added to the adder with Batcher.BatchAdder.add(Object). When the batch adder's batch is full, the batch is added to the queue and a new batch is started.

Processing Elements

A batcher has a set of worker threads that are started with start(Count), passing in the desired number of threads. Worker threads pull batches out of the queue and call Batcher.Batch.process() which calls onBatch(Batch) to let the subclass process the batch of elements. When the thread(s) that are adding elements to the batcher are done, they must call stop(), to shut down the batcher and wait until the processing of all batches is complete.

Example

 private static final Maximum QUEUE_SIZE = Maximum._128;
 private static final Count BATCH_SIZE = Count._16384;
 private static final Count WORKER_THREADS = Count._8;

   [...]

 var batcher = Batcher.create()
     .withName(qualifiedName())
     .withQueueSize(QUEUE_SIZE)
     .withBatchSize(BATCH_SIZE)
     .withConsumer(batch -> batch.forEach(this::add));

   [...]

 batcher.start(WORKER_THREADS);

    [...]

 batcher.adder().add(record);

    [...]

 batcher.close();
Author:
jonathanl (shibo)
